item.title: Rejecting Master for Main
item.description: Recently, I launched a new open source project. Unofficially called the Last First Letter Collab, the story is built using a writing pattern: a sentence‚Äôs first word must begin with the previous sentence’s last word’s last letter.

item.title: Episode 24. T-shaped Team Time
item.description: Scrum doesn’t have time for “that’s not my job” silos. 100% clarity and collaboration delivers the best results. In this episode, we discuss what being T-shaped means, and how any member of a team can help unblock a colleague, regardless of specialization.

item.title: Episode 23. Swarming
item.description: Team, team, team - we say all the time how Scrum focuses on the power of teams over individuals. Swarming - working together on a shared problem - is one example of how a Scrum team is stronger together.

item.title: Episode 22. Using Scrum for Marketing
item.description: Along with special guest Daniel Gale-Rosen, Alley’s Director of Marketing, Ken and John unpack how Scrum’s framework can be applied to marketing.

item.title: Episode 21. Sprint Reviews / Sprint Demos
item.description: Call it a Sprint Review or a Sprint Demo, but this Scrum ritual is all about transparency and iteration. Join special guest Michael Muniz as he helps us unpack the benefits of regularly sharing what the team has accomplished.

item.title: Episode 20. Scrum in a Remote Agency Environment
item.description: We say it every week: this show is about “practicing scrum in an agency environment.” To kick it up a notch, we’re also a fully remote agency.

item.title: Episode 19. Hunting for Impediments
item.description: A good scrum master removes impediments raised by the team. But, a great scrum master removes impediments before the team even knows they have them.

item.title: Episode 18. Scrum Metrics and Performance Tracking
item.description: STOP ‚Äî data time! On this episode, Alley’s VP of Product Strategy and resident data aficionado, Jeff Stanger, shares tips and tricks on how to gather and analyze Scrum metrics for single teams as well as entire organizations running Scrum@Scale.

item.title: Episode 17. Backlog Refinement
item.description: Adding items to a Product Backlog is easy. How do you keep what can become an overwhelming list of half-formed ideas in check?

item.title: Episode 16. No Bosses
item.description: Let’s dig into the concept of Coaching: a purposeful departure from top-down management. How does this relationship work in a flat organization?

item.title: Episode 15. Scrum Roles
item.description: The first bit of the oft-referenced 3-5-3 of Scrum, the three Scrum Roles provide clarity to teams by identifying primary owners of various project needs.

item.title: Episode 14. Scrum at Home
item.description: You’ve heard it said that Scrum works across a variety of industries, but what about the largest one: Homelife! Alley’s Chief Operating Officer, Bridget McNulty, educates John and Ken on how to use Scrum at home.

item.title: Episode 13. Make Work Visible
item.description: Foster transparency and ownership on your Scrum team by making work (both in-progress and completed) visible. Learn how ticketing hidden work, getting up close and personal with manual burndown charts, and supporting a full-team demoing will increase both productivity and team happiness.

item.title: Episode 12. I Love It When Sprint Planning Comes Together
item.description: A man! A plan! A canal! Panama! Paige Campbell joins Ken and John to help demystify Sprint Planning. Learn how proper planning leads to productive sprints.

item.title: Episode 11. Sprint Goals
item.description: How did your last sprint go? If you only judge sprints based on velocity, your team is only seeing the tip of the iceberg!

item.title: Episode 10. [LIVE SHOW] Rethinking the Daily Standup
item.description: Ken, John, and 60 of their closest coworkers & friends got together on a Zoom to talk about the Daily Standup.

item.title: Episode 9. Story Points
item.description: John and Ken take a deep dive into story points and discuss how to use them, their benefits over time-only estimates, and share some examples!

item.title: Episode 8. Agile Design
item.description: How do the cadence and depth of user experience research and design thinking map to Scrum? Alley’s VP of UX, Susan Finkelpearl, explains it all (in the name of the Pittsburgh Steelers).

item.title: Episode 7. Continuous Improvement with Kaizen
item.description: A Scrum team should be continuously working to improve their output, their process, and themselves. One way to foster this progress is through Kaizen tickets each sprint.

item.title: Episode 6. Bring a Buffer
item.description: How can you gracefully handle the inevitable interruptions and urgencies that crop up for your Scrum team sprint? By bringing a buffer to every sprint!

item.title: Episode 5. Sprint Retros
item.description: One of the ways to drive continuous improvement on a Scrum team is with the Sprint Retrospective. Listen to Ken, John, and special guest Jaimie Olmstead share how they maximize team growth and process improvement with this Scrum ritual.

item.title: Episode 4. Product Backlog
item.description: Scrum has two backlogs. This episode is about the Product Backlog, which contains all the work we might do in a project.

item.title: Episode 3. Interview with JJ Sutherland
item.description: Q&A with JJ Sutherland, the CEO of Scrum Inc and author of Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time and The Scrum Fieldbook.

item.title: Episode 2. Is Scrum too rigid?
item.description: Do the foundational rules of Scrum interfere with project productivity and flow? Let’s find out in this episode!

item.title: Episode 1. Why Scrum?
item.description: I work at Alley: a fully remote web agency. Back in 2018, we put the entire agency through an Agile transformation, and now are a dedicated Scrum@Scale shop.

item.title: Velocity is a means, not an end
item.description: Being a scrum master, I often worry if velocity looms too large for me. From project forecasting to sprint planning to team retrospectives, velocity metrics are up in my grill more than bratwurst at a Green Bay Packers tailgate.

item.title: Rule of Scrum
item.description: As a scrum master and coach, I see the phrase ‚Äúdoing scrum wrong‚Äù thrown around a lot. Scrum practitioners often worry about making missteps, while detractors lambast scrum as being unrealistic and too rigid for how ‚Äúthe real world works.

item.title: A fair way to get up to par with reference stories
item.description: Story pointing can feel a little wishy-washy, especially on teams that are new to scrum. While the inherent ambiguity to point estimation belies its power, folks need some place to hang their hat in grasping this concept.

item.title: A tale of two capacities
item.description: It was the best of sprints, it was the worst of sprints. One reason I find scrum so invigorating stems from its reliance on compiling lots and lots of data.

item.title: Sprint velocity - How scrum predicts the future
item.description: A common question I am asked is ‚ÄúHow will scrum deliver my projects on time?‚Äù and the honest answer is: it may not.

item.title: 2019 Resolutions - Three pluses, two minuses
item.description: I’m of the opinion that having one, solitary new year’s resolution is a bit of a cop-out. A single resolution, while admirable, is invariably too simple to fail (eat more salad) or too massive to be measurable (be a better person).

item.title: Leaving WordPress for GitHub Pages
item.description: I‚Äôve been a WordPress user since 2007, continuously maintaining personal writing sites. I grew along with the product, moving from a casual hobbyist suffering through the Famous 5-minute Install to a WordPress professional, making my living from the open source CMS.

item.title: Creating an ideal epic
item.description: What I like most about managing projects with Jira is the level of organization and filtering I can achieve by tagging tickets.

item.title: Hide on mobile - A `display none` allegory
item.description: Once upon a time, a traveler entered a nondescript pizza palace. On each of the red-and-white clothed tables were squat shakers of parmesan cheese and crushed red pepper.

item.title: WordPress, In crisis
item.description: One of the selling points for (the free software that is) WordPress is its user friendliness. Intuitive, accessible, open‚Äîall of these words are at the root of what WordPress is and why it is of such benefit to the publishing world.

item.title: Ixnay on the ‚Äúyou guys,‚Äù yous guys
item.description: Word choice is important, a fact not lost on famed Norse explorer Eric the Red. When he discovered a semi-inhabitable landmass northwest of his native Iceland, he knew he needed a snappy name to attract settlers.

item.title: Being bitten by bytes
item.description: Collective nouns are single words for a group of things and I love them all (except for ‚Äúguys‚Äù‚Äîthat‚Äôs a bad one).

item.title: Iterating ideas from draft to done
item.description: The writing process can make your brain feel like processed cheese (not to mention your self-esteem). Here are 10 steps for writing that will help you bridge the gap between one-and-done-drafts and that book chapter you‚Äôve been rewriting for years.

item.title: QA will give me a bug-free website and other lies we tell ourselves
item.description: If you work for a large corporation or on a project with limitless coffers, you have likely enjoyed working with a dedicated QA team.

item.title: Interrogative project management, A four-sonnet sequence on task-level discovery
item.description: Project management requires much asking Of clients and coders for more info So that a PM can get to tasking

item.title: The cost of a basic WordPress site
item.description: Stop me if you heard this one. A person walks up to a web developer and asks, ‚ÄúSo how much would it cost for, like, a basic website?

item.title: What is a CDN? A visual explanation
item.description: A CDN (Content Delivery Network),more commonplace in hosting plan offerings, is a must for any business site. By hosting web content on servers spread across the globe, content can be delivered to a user faster by using relatively localized servers.

item.title: How to succeed when working remotely - Lessons learned from a Chinese buffet
item.description: Working from home can be an amazingly fulfilling career experience. Likewise, a trip to your local Chinese food buffet can be a culinary delight.

item.title: Rethinking the WordPress writing experience
item.description: Before I was a web professional, before all the project management, front-end coding, and CMS rejiggering, I was an English major.

item.title: Seven things you can never say on project calls
item.description: The words we use communicate shades of meaning that we might not want. Here‚Äôs a list of seven words that I strive to not use when discussing a project with a client or with my team.

item.title: Hi, I'm John!
item.description: I’m the Director of Agile Process at Alley, a fully remote web agency running Scrum@Scale. The Scrum Master on the data visualization team, I work closely with all of Alley‚Äôs SMs, both as a collaborator and an Agile Coach.

item.title: Let's talk!
item.description: Reach out with questions, comments, or just to say hi üëãüèΩ john@ragozzine.me Contact me Name Email Your Message Send
